comments.html: Very interesting post, I was under the impression that Cisco was on the same track as HP and NetApp. Need to dwelve deeper into this! Thanks!
comments.name: Fredrik

comments.html:
Also, I don't think the link "you don’t need congestion control specified in 802.1Qau standard (or maybe you do)." works as intended.

Cheers!
comments.name: Fredrik

comments.html: Thanks for the feedback. A bug in my Word-to-HTML-through-XML/XSLT code.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
Ivan,
It's also possible to deploy a DCB switch that has FC visibility and forwarding intelligence, but is not a "full FCF running FSPF". Think of it like NPV for FCoE.

Cheers,
Brad
comments.name: Brad Hedlund

comments.html: Does deploying ciscos model impact the FC SAN domains? Is there still a logical limit of 24 (32) domains in a FC SAN when deploying FCOE?
comments.name: dbm

comments.html:
Obviously it's too early to have a definitive answer; we need to see a working product first 8-)

From a purely theoretical perspective: every FCoE switch with a VE_port is a FC domain. In theory, you could have up to 253 domains per FC SAN (not just 24), but I guess you're hitting limitations of your existing gear, in which case, you might consider NPV interface between FC and FCoE.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: The theoretical limit for FC domains is 239 according to the FC-SW standard. However, most vendors only support a limited number of domains per fabric purely from a testing/support point of view. Not sure what Cisco supports, but Brocade supports 56 domains per fabric. OEMs might have different support policies.
comments.name: Juan Tarrio Brocade
